Government policies are the primary forces that guide the decisions of firms and households.
questions.answer: Government policies are the primary forces that guide the decisions of firms and households.

questions.question: The decisions of firms and households are guided by prices and self-interest in a
options: command economy.
centrally-planned economy.
market economy.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: market economy.

questions.question: For markets to work well, there must be
options: market power.
a central planner.
property rights.
abundant, not scarce, resources.
questions.answer: property rights.

questions.question: Prices usually reflect
options: only the value of a good to society.
only the cost to society of making a good.
both the value of a good to society and the cost to society of making the good.
neither the value of a good to society nor the cost to society of making the good.
questions.answer: both the value of a good to society and the cost to society of making the good.

questions.question: Prices direct economic activity in a market economy by
options: influencing the actions of buyers and sellers.
reducing scarcity of the goods and services produced.
eliminating the need for government intervention.
allocating goods and services in the most equitable way.
questions.answer: influencing the actions of buyers and sellers.

questions.question: A friend of yours asks you why market prices are better than government-determined prices. Because you understand economic principles, you say that market-determined prices are better because they generally reflect
options: the value of a good to society, but not the cost of making it.
the cost of making a good to society, but not its value.
both the value of a good to society and the cost of making it.
neither the value of a good to society nor the cost of making it.
questions.answer: both the value of a good to society and the cost of making it.

questions.question: If the price of visiting a doctor were fixed below the current price, then we would expect
options: an increase in the number of visits people want to make and an increase in the number of visits health care providers want to provide.
an increase in the number of visits people want to make and a decrease in the number of visits health care providers want to provide.
a decrease in the number of visits people want to make and an increase in the number of visits health care providers want to provide.
a decrease in the number of visits people want to make and a decrease in the number of visits health care providers want to provide.
questions.answer: an increase in the number of visits people want to make and a decrease in the number of visits health care providers want to provide.

questions.question: If the rent for apartments in New York City were fixed below the current price, then we would expect
options: an increase in the number of people wanting to rent apartments in New York City.
a decrease in the number of people wanting to rent apartments in New York City.
an increase in the number of apartments available for rent in New York City.
None of the above is correct.
questions.answer: an increase in the number of people wanting to rent apartments in New York City.

questions.question: If the price of a dozen eggs were fixed above the current price, then we would expect
options: an increase in the number of eggs people want to buy and an increase in the number of eggs farmers want to sell.
an increase in the number of eggs people want to buy and a decrease in the number of eggs farmers want to sell.
a decrease in the number of eggs people want to buy and an increase in the number of eggs farmers want to sell.
a decrease in the number of eggs people want to buy and a decrease in the number of eggs farmers want to sell.
questions.answer: a decrease in the number of eggs people want to buy and an increase in the number of eggs farmers want to sell.

questions.question: If the wage for unskilled labor were fixed above the current wage, then we would expect
options: an increase in the number of unskilled jobs available.
a decrease in the number of unskilled jobs available.
a decrease in the number of workers wanting unskilled jobs.
None of the above is correct.
questions.answer: a decrease in the number of unskilled jobs available.

questions.question: When the government prevents prices from adjusting naturally to supply and demand,
options: it equates the amount buyers want to buy with the amount sellers want to sell.
it adversely affects the allocation of resources.
it improves equality and efficiency.
it improves efficiency but reduces equality.
questions.answer: it adversely affects the allocation of resources.

questions.question: One reason we need government, even in a market economy, is that
options: there is insufficient market power in the absence of government.
property rights are too strong in the absence of government.
the invisible hand is not perfect.
Both a and b are correct.
questions.answer: the invisible hand is not perfect.

questions.question: The government enforces property rights by
options: requiring property owners to pay property taxes.
providing police and courts.
forcing people to own property.
providing public parks and recreation facilities.
questions.answer: providing police and courts.

questions.question: A company that formerly produced software went out of business because too many potential customers bought illegally-produced copies of the software instead of buying the product directly from the company. This instance serves as an example of
options: market power.
inefficient trade.
inadequate enforcement of property rights.
the invisible hand at work.
questions.answer: inadequate enforcement of property rights.

questions.question: For which of the following problems can well-designed public policy enhance economic efficiency?
options: both externalities and market power
externalities, but not market power
market power, but not externalities
neither externalities nor market power
questions.answer: both externalities and market power

questions.question: Public policies
options: may be able to improve either economic efficiency or equality.
may be able to improve economic efficiency but cannot improve equality.
may be able to improve equality but cannot improve economic efficiency.
cannot improve either equality or economic efficiency.
questions.answer: may be able to improve either economic efficiency or equality.

questions.question: To say that government intervenes in the economy to promote efficiency is to say that government is attempting to
options: create a more fair distribution of income.
change the way in which the economic pie is divided.
enlarge the economic pie.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: enlarge the economic pie.

questions.question: Which of the following could reduce economic efficiency?
options: laws that encourage lawsuits
policies that redistribute income
policies that impose significant restrictions on international trade
All of the above are correct
questions.answer: All of the above are correct

questions.question: The term used to describe a situation in which markets do not allocate resources efficiently is
options: economic meltdown.
market failure.
equilibrium.
the effect of the invisible hand.
questions.answer: market failure.

questions.question: A rationale for government involvement in a market economy is
options: markets sometimes fail to produce a fair distribution of economic well-being.
markets sometimes fail to produce an efficient allocation of resources.
property rights have to be enforced.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: The term market failure refers to
options: a situation in which the market on its own fails to allocate resources efficiently.
an unsuccessful advertising campaign which reduces demand for a product.
a situation in which competition among firms becomes ruthless.
a firm which is forced out of business because of losses.
questions.answer: a situation in which the market on its own fails to allocate resources efficiently.

questions.question: Which of the following is not generally regarded by economists as a legitimate reason for the government to intervene in a market?
options: to promote efficiency
to promote equality
to enforce property rights
to protect an industry from foreign competition
questions.answer: to protect an industry from foreign competition

questions.question: Which of the following can lead to market failure?
options: externalities and market power
externalities but not market power
market power but not externalities
neither externalities nor market power
questions.answer: externalities and market power

questions.question: Causes of market failure include
options: externalities and market power.
market power and incorrect forecasts of consumer demand.
externalities and foreign competition.
incorrect forecasts of consumer demand and foreign competition.
questions.answer: externalities and market power.

questions.question: Market failure can be caused by
options: low consumer demand.
equilibrium prices.
externalities and market power.
high prices and foreign competition.
questions.answer: externalities and market power.

questions.question: Thousands of people develop lung cancer from second-hand exposure to cigarette smoke. This is an example of
options: a market failure caused by an externality.
a market failure caused by market power.
a market failure caused by equality.
There is no market failure in this case.
questions.answer: a market failure caused by an externality.

questions.question: When a species of fish dies off due to pollution in a river where it once lived, this is an example of
options: a market failure caused by an externality.
a market failure caused by market power.
a market failure caused by equality.
There is no market failure in this case.
questions.answer: a market failure caused by an externality.

questions.question: The term "market failure"
options: means the same thing as "market power."
refers to the dissolution of a market when firms decide to quit producing a certain product.
refers to the failure of a market to produce an efficient allocation of resources.
refers to government's failure to enforce the property rights of households or firms that participate in a certain market.
questions.answer: refers to the failure of a market to produce an efficient allocation of resources.

questions.question: If an externality is present in a market, economic efficiency may be enhanced by
options: government intervention.
a decrease in foreign competition.
fewer market participants.
weaker property rights.
questions.answer: government intervention.

questions.question: An example of an externality is the impact of
options: bad weather on the income of farmers.
the personal income tax on a person's ability to purchase goods and services.
pollution from a factory on the health of people in the vicinity of the factory.
increases in health care costs on the health of individuals in society.
questions.answer: pollution from a factory on the health of people in the vicinity of the factory.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an externality?
options: Annie purchases a handbag.
Bob's dog barks loudly during the night waking his neighbors.
Clark sells a book to Calvin.
David watches a scary movie.
questions.answer: Bob's dog barks loudly during the night waking his neighbors.

questions.question: The willingness of citizens to pay for vaccinations does not include the benefit society receives from having vaccinated citizens who cannot transmit an illness to others. This extra benefit society gets from vaccinating its citizens is known as
options: productivity.
an externality.
market power.
property rights.
questions.answer: an externality.

questions.question: If a paper factory does not bear the entire cost of the pollution it emits, it will
options: not emit any pollution so as to avoid the entire cost of the pollution.
emit lower levels of pollution.
emit an acceptable level of pollution.
emit too much pollution.
questions.answer: emit too much pollution.

questions.question: Laws that restrict the smoking of cigarettes in public places are examples of government intervention that is intended to reduce
options: efficiency.
equality.
externalities.
productivity.
questions.answer: externalities.

questions.question: Which of these activities will most likely impose an external cost?
options: An athlete works out at a gym.
A secretary smokes a cigarette in a crowded break room.
A young mother pushes her baby in a stroller.
A construction worker eats a hotdog during his lunch break.
questions.answer: A secretary smokes a cigarette in a crowded break room.

questions.question: Which of these activities will most likely impose an external cost?
options: Betty plants flowers in her garden.
Bonnie gets a flu vaccine.
Bridget drives her car after having too much alcohol to drink.
Becky buys a new flat screen television.
questions.answer: Bridget drives her car after having too much alcohol to drink.

questions.question: Which of these activities will most likely result in an external benefit?
options: A college student buys a deck of cards to play solitaire in her dorm room.
An elderly woman plants a flower garden on the vacant lot next to her house.
An executive purchases a book to read on a business trip.
A ten-year-old uses his allowance to buy new Nike shoes.
questions.answer: An elderly woman plants a flower garden on the vacant lot next to her house.

questions.question: Which of these activities will most likely result in an external benefit?
options: Jake purchases a dilapidated house and cleans up the yard and exterior of the house.
John purchases an iPhone and downloads new apps.
Jack purchases a new SUV and drives it to work every day.
Joe purchases a suit and wears it on his interviews.
questions.answer: Jake purchases a dilapidated house and cleans up the yard and exterior of the house.

questions.question: When a single person (or small group) has the ability to influence market prices, there is
options: competition.
market power.
an externality.
a lack of property rights.
questions.answer: market power.

questions.question: Market power refers to the
options: power of a single person or small group to influence market prices.
ability of a person or small group to successfully market new products.
power of the government to regulate a market.
importance of a certain market in relation to the overall economy.
questions.answer: power of a single person or small group to influence market prices.

questions.question: Which of the following firms is likely to have the greatest market power?
options: an electric company
a farmer
a grocery store
a local electronics retailer
questions.answer: an electric company

questions.question: Which of the following firms is most likely to have market power?
options: a grocery store in a metropolitan area
a gas station in a suburb
a pub in a college town
the only hotel in a rural area
questions.answer: the only hotel in a rural area

questions.question: An example of a firm with market power is a
options: delicatessen in New York.
cable TV provider in St. Louis.
clothing store in Los Angeles.
family farm in Illinois.
questions.answer: cable TV provider in St. Louis.

questions.question: The price of diamonds is high, in part because the majority of the world's diamonds are controlled by a single firm. This is an example of
options: a market failure caused by an externality.
a market failure caused by market power.
a market failure caused by equality.
There is no market failure in this case.
questions.answer: a market failure caused by market power.

questions.question: The ability of an individual to own and exercise control over scarce resources is called
options: market failure.
property rights.
externality.
market power.
questions.answer: property rights.

How The Economy As A Whole Works.title: How The Economy As A Whole Works

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In 2008, the average American earned about $47,000 while the average Nigerian earned about $1,400. Which of the following statements is likely?
options: The average American purchases more televisions than the average Nigerian.
The average American has better nutrition and healthcare than the average Nigerian.
The average American has a longer life expectancy than the average Nigerian.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In the United States, incomes historically have grown about 2 percent per year. At this rate, average income doubles every
options: 15 years.
25 years.
35 years.
45 years.
questions.answer: 35 years.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In the United States, incomes have historically grown
options: about 0.5 percent per year.
about 2 percent per year.
about 4 percent per year.
about 6 percent per year.
questions.answer: about 2 percent per year.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Over the past century, the average income in the United States has risen about
options: twofold.
fivefold.
eightfold.
tenfold.
questions.answer: eightfold.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The term "productivity"
options: means the same thing as "efficiency."
is seldom used by economists, as its meaning is not precise.
refers to the quantity of goods and services produced from each unit of labor input.
refers to the variety of goods and services from which households can choose when they shop.
questions.answer: refers to the quantity of goods and services produced from each unit of labor input.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Productivity is defined as the
options: amount of goods and services produced from each unit of labor input.
number of workers required to produce a given amount of goods and services.
amount of labor that can be saved by replacing workers with machines.
actual amount of effort workers put into an hour of working time.
questions.answer: amount of goods and services produced from each unit of labor input.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The amount of goods and services produced from each unit of labor input is called
options: opportunity cost.
productivity.
externality.
marginal benefit.
questions.answer: productivity.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: What is the most important factor that explains differences in living standards across countries?
options: the quantity of money
the level of unemployment
productivity
equality
questions.answer: productivity

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Almost all variation in living standards is attributable to differences in countries'
options: population growth rates.
productivity.
systems of public education.
taxes.
questions.answer: productivity.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The income of a typical worker in a country is most closely linked to which of the following?
options: population
productivity
market power
government policies
questions.answer: productivity

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: A direct or positive relationship exists between a country's
options: productivity and its standard of living.
amount of government spending and its productivity.
total population and its average citizen's income.
rate of population growth and the extent of its trade with other countries.
questions.answer: productivity and its standard of living.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The primary determinant of a country's standard of living is
options: the country's ability to prevail over foreign competition.
the country's ability to produce goods and services.
the total supply of money in the economy.
the average age of the country's labor force.
questions.answer: the country's ability to produce goods and services.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The historical rise in living standards of American workers is primarily a result of
options: the influence of labor unions in America.
tariff protection imposed by the American government.
the enactment of minimum-wage laws in America.
the rise in American productivity.
questions.answer: the rise in American productivity.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The fact that different countries experience different standards of living is largely explained by differences in those countries'
options: populations.
productivity levels.
locations.
None of the above is correct. Economists are puzzled by differences in standards of living around the world.
questions.answer: productivity levels.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Suppose that the average income of a Costa Rican is higher than the average income of a Guatemalan. You might conclude that
options: Costa Rican firms are faced with stricter government regulations than Guatemalan firms.
total income is divided among fewer workers in Costa Rica since it has a smaller labor force than Guatemala.
Guatemala's climate allows for longer growing seasons and therefore Guatemala can produce large quantities of grain and other crops.
productivity in Costa Rica is higher than in Guatemala.
questions.answer: productivity in Costa Rica is higher than in Guatemala.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The slow growth of U.S. incomes during the 1970s and 1980s can best be explained by
options: unstable economic conditions in Eastern Europe.
increased competition from abroad.
a decline in the rate of increase in U.S. productivity.
a strong U.S. dollar abroad, hurting U.S. exports.
questions.answer: a decline in the rate of increase in U.S. productivity.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Slow growth in US incomes during the 1970s and 1980s was primarily due to
options: slow productivity growth in the US.
increased competition from Japan.
increased competition from European countries.
a rapid decrease in the quantity of money in the economy.
questions.answer: slow productivity growth in the US.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Suppose a typical worker in India can produce 32 units of product in an eight-hour day, while a typical worker in Bangladesh can produce 30 units of product in a 10-hour day. We can conclude that
options: worker productivity in Bangladesh is higher than in India.
the standard of living will likely be higher in India than in Bangladesh.
productivity is 4 units per hour for the worker in Bangladesh and 3 units per hour for the worker in India.
there will be no difference between the standard of living in India and Bangladesh.
questions.answer: the standard of living will likely be higher in India than in Bangladesh.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Suppose that in Ireland total annual output is worth $600 million and people work 30 million hours. In Canada total annual output is worth $800 million and people work 50 million hours. Productivity is higher
options: in Ireland. Most variation in the standard of living across countries is due to differences in productivity.
in Ireland. Differences in productivity explain very little of the variation in the standard of living across countries.
in Canada. Most variation in the standard of living across countries is due to differences in productivity.
in Canada. Differences in productivity explain very little of the variation in the standard of living across countries.
questions.answer: in Ireland. Most variation in the standard of living across countries is due to differences in productivity.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: According to a recent study of Chilean bus drivers, drivers who are paid by the number of passengers they transport have higher productivity than drivers who are paid by the hour. If Chilean bus drivers are paid by the number of passengers they transport and Colombian bus drivers are paid by the hour, we can conclude that
options: Chilean bus drivers likely have a higher standard of living than Colombian bus drivers.
Colombian bus drivers likely have a higher standard of living than Chilean bus drivers.
Chilean and Colombian bus drivers likely have the same standard of living.
Chilean and Colombian bus drivers likely have a higher standard of living than US bus drivers.
questions.answer: Chilean bus drivers likely have a higher standard of living than Colombian bus drivers.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: US citizens have better nutrition, better healthcare, and a longer life expectancy than citizens of Ghana. Which of the following conclusions can be drawn from this statement?
options: Average income in the US is higher than the average income in Ghana.
The US has a higher standard of living than Ghana.
Productivity in the US is higher than productivity in Ghana.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In a particular country in 1998, the average worker needed to work 25 hours to produce 40 units of output. In that same country in 2008, the average worker needed to work 40 hours to produce 68 units of output. In that country, the productivity of the average worker
options: decreased by 1.7 percent between 1998 and 2008.
remained unchanged between 1998 and 2008.
increased by 4.75 percent between 1998 and 2008.
increased by 6.25 percent between 1998 and 2008.
questions.answer: increased by 6.25 percent between 1998 and 2008.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In a particular country in 2000, the average worker needed to work 40 hours to produce 55 units of output. In that same country in 2008, the average worker needed to work 30 hours to produce 45 units of output. In that country, the productivity of the average worker
options: decreased by about 6 percent between 2000 and 2008.
remained unchanged between 2000 and 2008.
increased by about 9 percent between 2000 and 2008.
increased by about 18 percent between 2000 and 2008.
questions.answer: increased by about 9 percent between 2000 and 2008.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In a particular country in 1998, the average worker needed to work 40 hours to produce 100 units of output. In that same country in 2008, the average worker needed to work 36 hours to produce 72 units of output. In that country, the productivity of the average worker
options: decreased between 1998 and 2008, so we would expect the standard of living to have decreased accordingly.
increased between 1998 and 2008, so we would expect the standard of living to have increased accordingly.
decreased between 1998 and 2008, so we would expect inflation to have decreased accordingly.
increased between 1998 and 2008, so we would expect inflation to have increased accordingly.
questions.answer: decreased between 1998 and 2008, so we would expect the standard of living to have decreased accordingly.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In a particular country in 1999, the average worker had to work 20 hours to produce 55 units of output. In that same country in 2009, the average worker needed to work 28 hours to produce 77 units of output. In that country, the productivity of the average worker
options: increased by 2 percent between 1999 and 2009.
increased by 5 percent between 1999 and 2009.
remained unchanged between 1999 and 2009.
decreased by 3 percent between 1999 and 2009.
questions.answer: remained unchanged between 1999 and 2009.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: A worker in Equador can earn $3 per day making cotton cloth on a hand loom. A worker in the United States can earn $70 per day making cotton cloth with a mechanical loom. What accounts for the difference in wages?
options: U.S. textile workers belong to a union.
There is little demand for cotton cloth in Equador and great demand in the U.S.
Labor is more productive making cotton cloth with a mechanical loom than with a hand loom.
Equador has a low-wage policy to make its textile industry more competitive in world markets.
questions.answer: Labor is more productive making cotton cloth with a mechanical loom than with a hand loom.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: To promote good economic outcomes, policymakers should strive to enact policies that
options: enhance productivity.
enhance individuals' market power.
result in a rapidly-growing quantity of money.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: enhance productivity.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: To raise productivity, policymakers could
options: increase spending on education.
provide tax credits to firms for capital improvements.
fund research and development.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: To increase living standards, public policy should
options: ensure that workers are well educated and have the necessary tools and technology.
make unemployment benefits more generous.
move workers into jobs directly from high school.
ensure a greater degree of equality, taking all income-earners into account.
questions.answer: ensure that workers are well educated and have the necessary tools and technology.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The increase in living standards of American workers over the past century is primarily due to
options: the success of labor unions.
minimum-wage laws.
improvements in productivity.
None of the above are correct.
questions.answer: improvements in productivity.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: To improve living standards, policymakers should
options: impose restrictions on foreign competition.
formulate policies designed to increase productivity.
impose tougher immigration policies.
provide tax breaks for the middle class.
questions.answer: formulate policies designed to increase productivity.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Incomes of U.S. households in the 1970s and 1980s
options: grew rapidly, due to the widespread success of labor unions in pushing up wages during those decades.
grew rapidly, due to several increases in the minimum wage during those decades.
grew rapidly, due to government policies that discouraged the importation of foreign products during those decades.
grew slowly, due to slow growth of the output of goods and services per hour of U.S. workers' time during those decades.
questions.answer: grew slowly, due to slow growth of the output of goods and services per hour of U.S. workers' time during those decades.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: An increase in the overall level of prices in an economy is referred to as
options: the income effect.
inflation.
deflation.
the substitution effect.
questions.answer: inflation.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Inflation is defined as
options: a period of rising productivity in the economy.
a period of rising income in the economy.
an increase in the overall level of output in the economy.
an increase in the overall level of prices in the economy.
questions.answer: an increase in the overall level of prices in the economy.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In the early 1920s,
options: Germany experienced a very high rate of inflation.
the quantity of German money was declining rapidly.
the value of German money remained almost constant.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: Germany experienced a very high rate of inflation.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: During the early 1920s in Germany, prices
options: doubled annually.
doubled monthly.
tripled monthly.
tripled annually.
questions.answer: tripled monthly.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In less than two years in the early 1920s, the cost of a German newspaper rose from 0.30 marks to 70,000,000 marks. This is a spectacular example of
options: market power caused by a change in the country's standard of living.
market power caused by a single firm controlling the newspaper production.
inflation caused by increased productivity in the economy.
inflation caused by an increase in the quantity of money in the economy.
questions.answer: inflation caused by an increase in the quantity of money in the economy.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: One of the 20th century's worst episodes of inflation occurred in
options: the United States in the 1960s.
Italy in the 1950s.
Russia in the 1930s.
Germany in the 1920s.
questions.answer: Germany in the 1920s.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In the United States, the overall level of prices more than doubled during the

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: President Gerald Ford referred to inflation as
options: a blight on our nation's economy.
a necessary evil to combat high unemployment.
public enemy number one.
a fly in the ointment.
questions.answer: public enemy number one.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The U.S. president who referred to inflation as "public enemy number one" was
options: Richard Nixon.
Gerald Ford.
Jimmy Carter.
Ronald Reagan.
questions.answer: Gerald Ford.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In which of the following decades was there both high inflation and rapid money supply growth in the US?
options: the 1970's and the 1990's
the 1970's but not the 1990's
the 1990's but not the 1970's
neither the 1970's nor the 1990's
questions.answer: the 1970's but not the 1990's

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In the 1990s, inflation in the United States was
options: very close to zero.
about 3 percent per year.
about 6 percent per year.
commonly referred to as "public enemy number one."
questions.answer: about 3 percent per year.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Large or persistent inflation is almost always caused by
options: excessive government spending.
excessive growth in the quantity of money.
foreign competition.
higher-than-normal levels of productivity.
questions.answer: excessive growth in the quantity of money.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Which of the following would a permanent increase in the growth rate of the money supply change permanently?
options: inflation
unemployment
both inflation and unemployment
neither inflation nor unemployment
questions.answer: inflation

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Most economists believe that an increase in the quantity of money results in
options: an increase in the demand for goods and services.
lower unemployment in the short run.
higher inflation in the long run.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In the short run, which of the following rates of growth in the money supply is likely to lead to the lowest level of unemployment in the economy?
options: 3 percent per year
5 percent per year
7 percent per year
9 percent per year
questions.answer: 9 percent per year

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In the short run, which of the following rates of growth in the money supply is likely to lead to the highest level of unemployment in the economy?
options: 1 percent per year
2 percent per year
3 percent per year
4 percent per year
questions.answer: 1 percent per year

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In the short run, an increase in the money supply is likely to lead to
options: lower unemployment and lower inflation.
lower unemployment and higher inflation.
higher unemployment and lower inflation.
higher unemployment and higher inflation.
questions.answer: lower unemployment and higher inflation.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Suppose that the Federal Reserve Bank announces that it will be making a change to a key interest rate to increase the money supply. This is likely because
options: the Federal Reserve Bank is worried about inflation.
the Federal Reserve Bank is worried about unemployment.
the Federal Reserve Bank is hoping to reduce the demand for goods and services.
the Federal Reserve Bank is worried that the economy is growing too quickly.
questions.answer: the Federal Reserve Bank is worried about unemployment.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Low rates of inflation are generally associated with
options: low rates of government spending.
small or nonexistent government budget deficits.
low rates of productivity growth.
low rates of growth of the quantity of money.
questions.answer: low rates of growth of the quantity of money.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Which of the following is the most correct statement about the relationship between inflation and unemployment?
options: In the short run, falling inflation is associated with falling unemployment.
In the short run, falling inflation is associated with rising unemployment.
In the long run, falling inflation is associated with falling unemployment.
In the long run, falling inflation is associated with rising unemployment.
questions.answer: In the short run, falling inflation is associated with rising unemployment.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Which of the following is an important cause of inflation in an economy?
options: increases in productivity in the economy
the influence of positive externalities on the economy
lack of property rights in the economy
growth in the quantity of money in the economy
questions.answer: growth in the quantity of money in the economy

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The mainstream view among economists is that
options: society faces a tradeoff between unemployment and inflation, but only in the short run.
society faces a tradeoff between unemployment and inflation, but only in the long run.
society faces a tradeoff between unemployment and inflation, both in the short run and in the long run.
no tradeoff exists between unemployment and inflation, either in the short run or in the long run.
questions.answer: society faces a tradeoff between unemployment and inflation, but only in the short run.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Which of the following claims is consistent with the views of mainstream economists?
options: If we increase the rate of inflation from 3 percent to 6 percent, then the rate of unemployment will temporarily fall.
If we increase the rate of inflation from 3 percent to 6 percent, then the rate of unemployment will temporarily rise.
If we increase the rate of inflation from 3 percent to 6 percent, then the rate of unemployment will permanently fall.
If we increase the rate of inflation from 3 percent to 6 percent, then the rate of unemployment will permanently rise.
questions.answer: If we increase the rate of inflation from 3 percent to 6 percent, then the rate of unemployment will temporarily fall.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: For a very long time Treeland has had an inflation rate of 9%. Suddenly its inflation rate drops to 3%. The drop in the inflation rate
options: could be due to slower money supply growth. We would expect unemployment to be higher.
could be due to slower money supply growth. We would expect unemployment to be lower.
could be due to higher money supply growth. We would expect unemployment to be higher.
could be due to higher money supply growth. We would expect unemployment to be lower.
questions.answer: could be due to slower money supply growth. We would expect unemployment to be higher.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: For a number of years country A had inflation of 3% but for the last five years has had inflation of 6%. Country B had inflation of 4% for many years, but very recently inflation unexpectedly rose to 9%. Other things the same, in which of the countries would the higher inflation rate be more likely to reduce unemployment?
options: both country A and country B
neither country A nor country B
country A but not country B
country B but not country A
questions.answer: country B but not country A

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In the early 1980s, U.S. economic policy was directed toward reducing inflation. What would you have expected to observe during this short period of time?
options: Inflation fell and unemployment fell.
Inflation and unemployment were both unaffected.
Inflation fell and unemployment increased.
Inflation fell and unemployment was unchanged.
questions.answer: Inflation fell and unemployment increased.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The relatively low inflation experienced in the United States in the 1990s is attributable to
options: slow growth of U.S. productivity during the 1990s.
slow growth of the quantity of money in the U.S. in the 1990s.
low levels of government spending in the U.S. in the 1980s and 1990s.
the eight-year presidency of William Jefferson Clinton during the 1990s.
questions.answer: slow growth of the quantity of money in the U.S. in the 1990s.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: During the 1990s, the United Kingdom experienced low levels of inflation while Turkey experienced high levels of inflation. A likely explanation of these facts is that
options: the United Kingdom has a better education system than Turkey.
the rate of growth of the quantity of money was slower in the United Kingdom than in Turkey.
workers in Turkey are more productive than workers in the United Kingdom.
there are more instances of market power in Turkey than in the United Kingdom.
questions.answer: the rate of growth of the quantity of money was slower in the United Kingdom than in Turkey.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The tradeoff between inflation and unemployment
options: implies that policies designed to reduce unemployment also reduce inflation.
was eliminated by improved economic policies in the 1900s.
is a long-run tradeoff, persisting for decades, according to most economists.
None of the above are correct.
questions.answer: None of the above are correct.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Germany could have avoided the high inflation that it experienced in the 1920s by
options: not directing so many of its resources toward preparation for World War II.
not increasing taxes so much on the German middle class.
not allowing the quantity of money to increase so rapidly.
using government policies to stimulate the economy more so than what was done.
questions.answer: not allowing the quantity of money to increase so rapidly.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In the short run, which of the following is not correct?
options: Increasing the money supply increases the demand for goods and services.
Increasing the money supply encourages firms to hire more workers.
Lowering the money supply leads to a higher level of unemployment.
Policies that encourage higher employment will also induce a lower rate of inflation.
questions.answer: Policies that encourage higher employment will also induce a lower rate of inflation.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: In response to the deep economic downturn in the US in 2008 and 2009, the US
options: reduced taxes.
increased government spending.
increased the supply of money.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The combination of President Obama's strategies and the Federal Reserve's reaction to the deep economic downturn in the US in 2008 and 2009
options: intended to reduce unemployment.
may lead to excessive inflation over time.
resulted in higher taxes and an increased supply of money.
Both a and b are correct.
questions.answer: Both a and b are correct.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The short-run tradeoff between inflation and unemployment implies that, in the short run,
options: a decrease in the growth rate of the quantity of money will be accompanied by an increase in the unemployment rate.
an increase in the growth rate of the quantity of money will be accompanied by an increase in the unemployment rate.
policymakers are able to reduce the inflation rate and, at the same time, reduce the unemployment rate.
policymakers can influence the inflation rate, but not the unemployment rate.
questions.answer: a decrease in the growth rate of the quantity of money will be accompanied by an increase in the unemployment rate.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The business cycle is the
options: relationship between unemployment and inflation.
irregular fluctuations in economic activity.
positive relationship between the quantity of money in an economy and inflation.
predictable changes in economic activity due to changes in government spending and taxes.
questions.answer: irregular fluctuations in economic activity.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The business cycle is measured by the
options: production of goods and services.
number of people employed.
the interest rate.
Both a and b are correct.
questions.answer: Both a and b are correct.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Irregular fluctuations in economic activity are known as the
options: business cycle.
broken window fallacy.
tradeoff between inflation and unemployment.
ten principles of economics.
questions.answer: business cycle.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Both the production of goods and services and the unemployment rate are used to measure
options: the business cycle.
productivity.
the interest rate.
inflation.
questions.answer: the business cycle.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: The "broken window fallacy"
options: explains why inflation is so high.
is a justification for the government to print more money.
is illustrated when a government program is justified not on its merits but on the number of jobs it will create.
has nothing to do with public policy.
questions.answer: is illustrated when a government program is justified not on its merits but on the number of jobs it will create.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: When a government program is justified not on its merits but on the number of jobs it will create,
options: the program is an efficient use of taxpayer dollars.
it should be approved only if the unemployment rate is low.
taxes should be raised to fund the program.
it is known as the "broken window fallacy."
questions.answer: it is known as the "broken window fallacy."

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: It once took 90 percent of our population to grow our food. It now takes only 3 percent of the population to grow our food. Which of the following statements is true?
options: This loss of jobs has been detrimental to our economy.
The government should provide subsidies to encourage more people to become farmers.
This reduction in the number of farmers explains the increase in the price of food.
This is progress because freed-up labor that is used to produce other goods.
questions.answer: This is progress because freed-up labor that is used to produce other goods.

questions.topic: How The Economy As A Whole Works
questions.question: Congressman Dearmark justified spending $3 million on a new entertainment complex in his district because it will create 450 new jobs for his residents. As a student of economics, you know that
options: this is a case of the "broken window fallacy."
this is a great use of taxpayer dollars.
this policy diverts money from spending somewhere else in the economy.
Both a and c are correct.
questions.answer: Both a and c are correct.
